'''Geoffrey Burel of Ambois'''e (d. 1101) was Lord of Amboise ''[[jure uxoris]]'' and a knight in the Crusade of 1101, fighting in the [[Army of William IX on the Crusade of 1101|army of William IX]]. Note that this individual is not the same as the Geoffrey Burel who was a commander in the service of [[Peter the Hermit]].
Geoffrey was arranged to be married to [[Corba of Thorigne]], Lady of Amboise, the daughter of the son-in-law of [[Fulk IV, Count of Anjou|Fulk IV le Réchin, Count of Anjou]]. Widowed twice, Corba’s marriage was arranged by Fulk to maintain control of the estates of [[Amboise]].
As was typical of the army of William, in which wives accompanied their husbands on crusade, Corba went with Geoffrey to the Holy Land. Geoffrey was killed at the battled of Heraclea and Corba was abducted by the Turks and never heard from again.
== Sources == * Riley-Smith, Jonathan, ''The First Crusaders, 1095-1131'', Cambridge University Press, London, 1997 * Prof. J. S. C. Riley-Smith, Prof, Jonathan Phillips, Dr. Alan V. Murray, Dr. Guy Perry, Dr. Nicholas Morton, ''A Database of Crusaders to the Holy Land, 1099-1149'' (available [https://www.hrionline.ac.uk/crusaders/ on-line]) * Duby, Georges, The Knight, the Lady and the Priest: The Making of Modern Marriage in Medieval France, University of Chicago Press, 1983, pgs 246-7 (available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=cIwUUYH4E3oC&pg=PA246&lpg=PA246&dq=corba+lady+of+amboise&source=bl&ots=__1w5vcCbh&sig=5PPRhDwjXD-2_NgZTNAxjCVXXFw&hl=en&sa=X&sqi=2&ved=0ahUKEwj8xqmO_KPTAhXrxFQKHQ_uAloQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=corba%20lady%20of%20amboise&f=false Google Books]) * Riley-Smith, Jonathan, The First Crusade and Idea of Crusading, A&C Black, 2003 (available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=t2t4_JG1xfIC&pg=PA121&lpg=PA121&dq=corba+lady+of+amboise&source=bl&ots=lbruh77FPC&sig=N6gmv4b3uQ20bYj8aoMIb1G85P8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2vbrmyqbTAhXCrlQKHWZzC7kQ6AEIQDAF#v=onepage&q=corba%20lady%20of%20amboise&f=false Google Books])

[[File:Grace Oakeshott died 1929.jpg|thumb|Grace - before she faked her death]] '''Grace Oakeshott''' (born '''Grace Cash''', later '''Joan Reeve'''; 1872–1929) was a British activist for women's rights who faked her own death in 1907 and emigrated to New Zealand with her lover, Walter Reeve.
Grace Cash was born in 1872.<ref name="Robson2016">{{cite book|last=Robson|first=J.|title=Radical Reformers and Respectable Rebels: How the Two Lives of Grace Oakeshott Defined an Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hdp6DAAAQBAJ&pg=PR17|date=16 June 2016|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|isbn=978-1-137-31184-9|pages=17–}}</ref> She married Harold Oakeshott and both were active in socialist circles. Grace wrote a paper in 1900 on ''Women in the Cigar Trade in London'', published in ''[[The Economic Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Oakeshott|first1=Grace|title=Women in the Cigar Trade in London|journal=The Economic Journal|date=1900|volume=10|issue=40|pages=562–572|jstor=2956851}}</ref> She was involved in the foundation of the first Trade School for Girls in 1904, and in the [[Women's Industrial Council]].<ref name=bynum />
In 1907 a pile of her clothes was found on a beach in [[Brittany]] where she was on holiday, giving the impression that she had drowned. In fact she had made plans to emigrate to New Zealand with her lover Dr Walter Reeve, apparently with the knowledge of her husband, at a time when divorce was difficult and scandalous. The supposed widower, Harold Oakeshott, later married again, bigamously.<ref name=bynum />
In New Zealand Oakeshott used the name Joan Reeve, and had three children with Walter Reeve. She died of [[multiple sclerosis]] in 1929 in New Zealand.<ref name=bynum />
==Legacy== Oakeshott was the subject of the play ''Grace'', written and directed by her great-granddaughter Sophie Dingemans, which was performed at Wellington's [[BATS Theatre]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Love story leaves lingering queries|url=http://www.theatreview.org.nz/reviews/review.php?id=1627|publisher=Theatre Review|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref>
Her life has been extensively researched by British author Jocelyn Robson, who published ''Radical Reformers and Respectable Rebels: How the Two Lives of Grace Oakeshott Defined an Era'' (2016, Palgrave Macmillan {{ISBN|9781137311832}}).<ref name=bynum>{{cite news|last1=Bynum|first1=Helen|title=Radical Reformers and Respectable Rebels: How the Two Lives of Grace Oakeshott Defined an Era, by Jocelyn Robson|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/books/review-radical-reformers-and-respectable-rebels-jocelyn-robson-palgrave-macmillan|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Times Higher Education|date=17 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="rnz">{{cite web|title=How Grace Oakeshott faked her death in 1907 and fled to New Zealand|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/ninetonoon/audio/201795803/how-grace-oakeshott-faked-her-death-in-1907-and-fled-to-new-zealand|publisher=Radio New Zealand|accessdate=7 September 2016|date=6 April 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Iwao Takamoto | image = HBIwao&Me.jpg | caption = Takamoto (at center) with [[William Hanna|Bill Hanna]], [[Joseph Barbera|Joe Barbera]] and Christopher Bracher, July 14, 1996 | birth_date = April 29, 1925 | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], California, US | death_date = January 8, 2007 (aged 81) | death_place = Los Angeles, California, U.S. | resting_place = [[Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] | occupation = [[Animator]], [[television producer]], [[film director]] | spouse = {{marriage|Jane M. Baer|1957|1959|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Barbara Farber|1964}} | parents = | children = 2 }} '''Iwao Takamoto''' (April 29, 1925 – January 8, 2007) was an [[Americans|American]] [[animator]], [[television producer]], and [[film director]]. He began his career as a [[production designer|production]] and character designer for [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] films such as ''[[Cinderella (1950 film)|Cinderella]]'' (1950), ''[[Lady and the Tramp]]'' (1955), and ''[[Sleeping Beauty (1959 film)|Sleeping Beauty]]'' (1959). Later, he moved to [[Hanna-Barbera Productions]], where he designed a great majority of the characters, including [[Scooby-Doo (character)|Scooby-Doo]] and [[The Jetsons|Astro]], and eventually became a director and producer. ==Early life and career== Takamoto was born in [[Los Angeles]], California. His father emigrated from [[Hiroshima]]{{cite news| url= http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/obituary/0,,2000879,00.html | title= Iwao Takamoto: Brilliant animator who eased the medium's transition from film to television| first= Paul |last= Wells| date= January 28, 2007 | work=[[The Guardian]] | accessdate= April 21, 2016}} to the United States for his health, and returned to Japan only once, to marry his wife. At 15 years of age, Takamoto graduated from [[Jefferson High School (Los Angeles)|Thomas Jefferson High School]] in [[Los Angeles]]. After the bombing of [[Pearl Harbor]], Takamoto's family, like many Japanese Americans, was forced to move to an [[Japanese American internment|internment camp]]. They spent the rest of [[World War II]] in the [[Manzanar]] internment camp. It was there that Takamoto received basic illustration training from two co-internees. Takamoto first entered the cartoon world after the end of the war. Without the benefit of a formal portfolio of his work, he created a sketchbook of, by his own admission, "everything I saw". It was based on this sketchbook that he applied to work at the Disney studios. He was hired as an assistant animator by [[List of assets owned by Disney#Studio Entertainment|Walt Disney Studios]] in 1945. Takamoto eventually became an assistant to [[Milt Kahl]]. He worked as an animator and character designer on such titles as ''[[Cinderella (1950 film)|Cinderella]]'' (1950), ''[[Peter Pan (1953 film)|Peter Pan]]'' (1953), ''[[Lady and the Tramp]]'' (1955), ''[[Sleeping Beauty (1959 film)|Sleeping Beauty]]'' (1959), and ''[[One Hundred and One Dalmatians]]'' (1961). ==Hanna-Barbera== Takamoto left Disney in 1961 and joined Hanna-Barbera Productions. He worked in several positions there, but is arguably best known as a character designer. He was responsible for the original character design of such characters as [[Scooby-Doo (character)|Scooby-Doo]], ''[[The Jetsons]]''' dog [[Astro (The Jetsons)|Astro]], and [[Penelope Pitstop]]. He worked as a producer at Hanna-Barbera, supervising shows such as ''[[The Addams Family (1973 animated series)|The Addams Family]]'', ''[[Hong Kong Phooey]]'', and ''[[Jabberjaw]]''. He directed several feature length animated films, including ''[[Charlotte's Web (1973 film)|Charlotte's Web]]'' (1973) and ''[[Jetsons: The Movie]]'' (1990). The inspiration for Scooby-Doo's creation as a [[Great Dane]] came from an employee of the Hanna-Barbera company, who bred this dog. Takamoto was Vice-President of Creative Design at Hanna-Barbera and was responsible for overseeing [[Hanna-Barbera|Hanna-Barbera's]] many merchandising lines as well as design work for their Animation Art Dept. In 1996, he received the [[Winsor McCay Award]] for lifetime achievement and contributions in the animation field. In 2005 he received the Golden Award from the [[Animation guild|Animation Guild]], to honor his more than 50 years of service in the animation field. After [[Time-Warner]] merged with (then owner of Hanna-Barbera Studios) [[Turner Broadcasting]] in 1996, Takamoto became Vice President of Special Projects for Warner Brothers Animation.{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Susan|title=Iwao Takamoto, 81, the Animation Artist Who Created Scooby-Doo, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/10/arts/television/10takamoto.html?_r=0|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 10, 2007}} ==Personal life== Iwao Takamoto married Jane M. (née Shattuck) Baer in 1957. They met at Disney while working on the animated feature ''[[Sleeping Beauty]]'' (1959) and were married for almost seven years. They had one son together, Michael. In 1963, he met Barbara Farber, who was the assistant to the public relations director at Hanna-Barbera, Arnie Carr. Part of her job was studio tours, which was how she and Takamoto met. Takamoto married Barbara in 1964 and remained married to her for 44 years, until his death in 2007. Barbara had a daughter from a former marriage, Leslie. ==Death== Takamoto died on January 8, 2007 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the age of 81. Throughout the week following his death, [[Adult Swim]] put up a bumper reading "Iwao Takamoto [1925-2007]". He is buried at [[Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Los Angeles]] in Gardens of Blessing, Section 3, Lot 1390, Space 3.{{cite news |title=Scooby-Doo designer dies in L.A. |url=http://today.reuters.com/news/articlenews.aspx?type=entertainmentNews&storyid=2007-01-09T052341Z_01_N08423986_RTRUKOC_0_US-TAKAMOTO.xml |publisher=Reuters |date=2007-01-09 |accessdate=2007-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224060440/http://today.reuters.com/news/articlenews.aspx?type=entertainmentNews&storyid=2007-01-09T052341Z_01_N08423986_RTRUKOC_0_US-TAKAMOTO.xml |archivedate=2007-02-24 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Scooby-Doo's creator dies aged 81 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6243717.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-01-08 |accessdate=2007-01-10 }} There was a memorial added to the end of the Scooby-Doo film ''[[Chill Out, Scooby-Doo!]]''. ==Awards and legacy == Takamoto received the [[Winsor McCay Award]], the lifetime achievement award from the [[International Animated Film Association]] (ASIFA) Hollywood. He received an honorary citation from the [[Japanese American National Museum]]. In 2005, he was given a golden award from the Animation Guild. Takamoto's memoirs were published posthumously in 2009 by [[University Press of Mississippi]] as ''Iwao Takamoto: My Life with a Thousand Characters'' by Iwao Takamoto and Michael Mallory. An intimate memoir, ''Living With A Legend'', was published posthumously in 2012 by [[TotalRecall Press]] by his stepdaughter, Leslie E. Stern. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|Asian Americans|Japan|Television in the United States|Cartoon}} * [[Scooby-Doo (character)|Scooby-Doo]] - [[television series]] * [[William Hanna]] * [[Joseph Barbera]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book| last=Takamoto| first=Iwao| year= 2009| url= https://books.google.com/?id=00B68sB1-CkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Iwao+Takamoto+:+my+life+with+a+thousand+characters#v=onepage&q=Iwao%20Takamoto%20%3A%20my%20life%20with%20a%20thousand%20characters&f=false |title= Iwao Takamoto: My life with a Thousand Characters| location= Jackson, Mississippi| publisher= University Press of Mississippi| isbn=9781604734775}} * {{cite book| last=Stern| first= Leslie| year=2012| title= Living With A Legend| publisher=TotalRecall Publications|isbn= 1590950968}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|name=Iwao Takamoto|id=0847314}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070202005322/http://www.cartoonbrew.com/archives/2007_01.html January 1999 interview in ''Animation Blast'' #3] (archived) * {{Find a Grave|17361774}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Takamoto, Iwao}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Japanese descent]] [[Category:American film directors of Japanese descent]] [[Category:Japanese-American internees]] [[Category:Artists from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Hanna-Barbera people]] [[Category:Walt Disney Animation Studios people]] [[Category:American animators]] [[Category:Animated film directors]] [[Category:Film directors from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Burials at Mount Sinai Memorial Park Cemetery]] [[Category:Deaths from heart-related cause]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2015}}
'''Jay Ferdinand Towner III''' (1910 – November 11, 1933)<ref name=ken>''College Press Urged To Bare Death Clews'', [[Washington Post]], November 17, 1933, pg. 4.</ref> was a youth from [[Perryman, Maryland]] who was found dead on the campus of [[Princeton University]] shortly after a Princeton versus [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] football game, in 1933. The mystery of Towner's death was taken up by [[United States Senator]] [[Millard Tydings]].
==Death circumstances and investigation== Towner was discovered a few hours after the game with both of his wrists fractured and internal injuries. However, there was no indication that he had been the victim of [[Crime|foul play]] or hit by a car. Authorities thought perhaps he had been crushed against the wall of [[Palmer Stadium]], while the crowd was exiting from the game. He later died from his injuries as he walked across the Princeton campus. Other information contended that Towner was in one of Princeton's dormitories following the football game. Another source said that he was seen in an automobile parking area.<ref name=deep/>
Three Princeton students reported seeing Towner in the undergraduate cheering section during the game. Princeton police were told on November 13 that Towner was seen falling down the concrete steps of the stadium during the football contest. This occurred during the most exciting part of the game when Princeton scored the only touchdown. Towner rose from his seat, tripped and fell down five concrete steps, landing on his hands. He was assisted to his seat by other spectators, appearing to be uninjured.<ref>''Three Say Towner Fell Before He Died'', Washington Post, November 14, 1933, pg. 19.</ref> Editors of the ''[[Daily Princetonian]]'' established that Towner was not pinned and crushed against a concrete wall by the departing crowd.<ref name=ken/>
Tydings received the cooperation of [[New Jersey Governor]] [[A. Harry Moore]] on November 20, 1933. Moore requested a report from prosecutor Erwin E. Marshall and [[Mercer County, New Jersey]] chief of detectives, James Kirkham.<ref name=deep>''Death At Princeton Taken Up By Moore'', [[New York Times]], November 21, 1933, pg. 28.</ref>
Towner's death was the second unexplained and violent demise on the Princeton campus within a month's time. On October 9, 1933 John Tighe, a janitor, was discovered dead between two Princeton buildings. His skull was fractured and he had fractures of one arm and several ribs, as well as internal injuries. It was surmised that Tighe had fallen from a building or been hit by a car. However, there was no evidence to support either hypothesis.<ref name=ken/>
==See also== {{portal|Maryland|New Jersey}} *[[List of unsolved deaths]]
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tower, Jay Ferdinand}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1933 deaths]] [[Category:Princeton University]] [[Category:People from Perryman, Maryland]] [[Category:Mercer County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Unsolved deaths]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:SirJohnAcland BroadclystChurch.JPG|thumb|Detail from Acland's recumbent effigy on his monument in Broadclyst Church, Devon]] [[File:AclandMonument Broadclyst.JPG|thumb|Acland's monument, Broadclyst Church]] [[File:Arms of Acland.svg|thumb|150px|Arms of Acland: ''Chequy argent and sable, a fesse gules'']] '''Sir John Acland''' ({{circa|1552}} – 1620) of [[Columbjohn|Columb John]] in the parish of [[Broadclyst]], Devon, was an English knight, landowner, philanthropist, Member of Parliament and [[Sheriff of Devon]]. He was one of [[John Prince (biographer)|John Prince's]] ''Worthies of Devon''.
==Origins== He was the second son of [[John Acland (died 1553)|John Acland]] (died 1553), of [[Acland, Landkey|Acland]] in the parish of [[Landkey]], Devon, by his wife Mary Redcliff, daughter and co-heiress of Hugh Redcliff of [[Stepney]] near London. He is said by [[John Prince (biographer)|Prince]] (c.1697) to have been the favourite son of his mother, who thus made him heir to her lands in and about London.<ref name=P2>Prince, p.2</ref> His elder brother was Hugh Acland (died 1622), who inherited the paternal estate of Acland, which he modernised in 1591<ref name=A5>Acland, Anne, p.5</ref> as attested by a surviving date stone,<ref>[[Nikolaus Pevsner|Pevsner, Nikolaus]] & Cherry, Bridget, The Buildings of England: Devon, London, 2004, p.125</ref> where he remained throughout his life.<ref name=A4>Acland, Anne, p.4</ref>
==Career== Acland was appointed to the county bench as a [[Justice of the Peace]] in 1583 and was [[Sheriff of Devon]] for 1608–09. He was elected Member of Parliament firstly for [[Saltash (UK Parliament constituency)|Saltash]], in 1586.<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=63|title=Acland, John|first=Wolffe|last=Mary}}</ref> He was knighted by King [[James I of England|James I]] on 15 March 1604 in the [[Tower of London]], and at a by-election on 27 January 1607, in the first parliament of the reign, became MP for [[Devon (UK Parliament constituency)|Devon]].
==Marriages== [[File:ElizabethRolle AclandMonument Broadclyst.JPG|thumb|upright|Effigy of Acland's wife Elizabeth Rolle, in Broadclyst Church]] Acland married twice, but left no surviving children. His first wife was Elizabeth Rolle, a daughter of the wealthy [[George Rolle]], of [[Stevenstone]] near [[Great Torrington]] in Devon, and the widow of Robert Mallet, of [[Woolleigh, Beaford|Woolleigh]],<ref name=V4>Vivian, p.4</ref> [[Beaford]], near Great Torrington<ref>Prince, p.2 "Woolley", today's "Woolleigh Barton", about 3 miles SE of Great Torrington</ref> in the same county. During Elizabeth's lifetime the couple lived at Woolleigh.<ref name=P2 /> It was probably due to Elizabeth's wealth that Acland was able to purchase the manor of Columb John<ref name=A4 /> in the parish of [[Broadclyst]]. On his monument in Broadclyst Church a kneeling effigy representing Elizabeth Rolle kneels by his head,<ref name=P4n>Prince, p.4 mentions these effigies, "one at the head and one at the feet"</ref> below a heraldic escutcheon displaying the arms of Rolle. By Elizabeth he had only one child, a daughter named Dorothy who died an infant.<ref name=V4 />
After Elizabeth died, Acland married Margaret Portman, another "vastly rich"<ref name=P2 /> widow, a daughter of [[Portman baronets|Sir Henry Portman]], of [[Orchard Portman]]<ref name=P2 /> in [[Somerset]] and the widow of Sir Gabriel Hawley (died 1604)<ref>Will proved 16 Mar 1603/1604 (Prerogative Court of Canterbury,: 47 Harte, quoted in [http://histfam.familysearch.org/getperson.php?personID=I116913&tree=Nixon])</ref> of [[Buckland Priory]] (''Buckland Sororum''),<ref>[[History of Parliament]] biog. of Sir John Acland</ref> in the parish of [[Dursley]], Somerset, [[High Sheriff of Somerset]] in 1584.<ref>Dunning, Robert (1983). A History of Somerset. Chichester: Phillimore & Co. pp. 109–117</ref> The marriage was childless. On Acland's monument in Broadclyst Church a kneeling effigy representing Margaret Portman kneels by his feet<ref name=P4n /> below a heraldic escutcheon displaying the arms of Portman.
==Lands acquired== He purchased the manor of Columb John<ref name=A4 /> in the parish of [[Broadclyst]], about 32 miles south-east of Acland, where he re-built the old manor house and its domestic chapel,<ref name=A4 /> which he endowed with the annual sum of £25 in eternity "for the encouragement of a chaplain, to preach and read prayers in it every Lord's day".<ref>Prince, p.3</ref>
The nearby manor of [[Killerton]], adjacent to Columb John, was not purchased at this time, but by Acland's eldest nephew Sir [[Arthur Acland (died 1610)|Arthur Acland]]<ref>[[Tristram Risdon|Risdon, Tristram]] (died 1640), Survey of Devon, 1810 edition, London, 1810, p.59, purchased from Sir Thomas Drewe; Vivian, p.307, pedigree of Drewe, states "Sir Thomas Drewe...sold Killerton to Sir Arthur Acland, Bart. (sic)"</ref> (died 1610) of Acland,<ref>Buried in Landkey Church, where his large monument survives</ref> whose son [[Sir John Acland, 1st Baronet]] (died 1647) deserted Acland and moved his residence to Columb John. Killerton was first used as a residence for Sir Arthur's widow Eleanor Mallet,<ref>Acland, Anne, p.6</ref> (daughter and heiress of Robert Mallet of Woolleigh,<ref name=V4 /> whose wife was Elizabeth Rolle who remarried to Sir John Acland (died 1620)). Killerton became the family's chief seat after 1672,<ref>Pevsner, p.518</ref> when the 1st baronet's fourth son [[Sir Hugh Acland, 5th Baronet]] (died 1713) altered and enlarged the house in 1680 and abandoned Columb John,<ref>Acland, Anne, p.13</ref> of which all that survives today is the Elizabethan gateway.<ref name=H352>[[William George Hoskins|Hoskins, W.G.]], A New Survey of England: Devon, London, 1959 (first published 1954), p.352</ref> His descendants later built the surviving Georgian [[Killerton|Killerton House]].
==Death and burial== Acland died on 14 February 1620,<ref>Vivian, p.4; "1620" per Acland, Anne, p.5</ref> and was buried in [[Broad Clyst]] church, where a monument he had commissioned himself,<ref name=A5 /> dated 1613,<ref name=P4>Prince, p.4</ref> survives in Broadclyst Church, showing the sculpted figures of himself and his wives. Since he died childless, his heir was his 70-year-old elder brother Hugh Acland (died 1622) of Acland.<ref name=V4 />
==Philanthropy== [[File:Exeter Dining Hall.JPG|thumb|Dining Hall, Exeter College, Oxford, built in 1618,<ref>http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-244919-exeter-college-south-range-main-quadrang</ref> largely financed by Acland]] His charitable gifts were numerous. He settled on the mayor and city council of [[Exeter]] the rectorial endowments of two parishes in the South Hams, so that the annual proceeds might be distributed among the poor in Exeter and in other parts of the county. He largely financed a new hall, with cellars underneath, at [[Exeter College, Oxford]], shortly before his death, at a cost of about £800 of the total £1,000 building cost.<ref name=P4 /> Two scholarships were also founded by him at the college. He gave money to buy bread for the poor in each of the 27 parishes in which he held land<ref>Acland, Anne., pp.4–5</ref> and an inscription to Sir John was erected in Pilton Church, near Acland, which is transcribed in [[Dean Milles' Questionnaire]] thus:<ref>Reproduced in Acland, Anne, p.5 & footnote 2 to chap. 2</ref> <poem>Here Sr John Acland to the poor's a friend, In giving bread noe times to have an end, Sixpence a week by him to us is measured, A crown for him in Heaven's laid up and treasured</poem>
==Monument== [[File:AclandAchievementBroadclyst.JPG|thumb|upright|Acland's Heraldic [[Achievement (heraldry)|achievement]]]] Sir John Acland's monument in Broadclyst Church was described by Pevsner as "one of the most sumptuous Jacobean monuments in Devon and the most splendid of a related group".<ref name=Pev215>Pevsner, p.215</ref> It was commissioned by Sir John during his lifetime<ref name=A5 /> and bears the dates 1613<ref name=P5>Prince, p.5</ref> and 1614.<ref>Above heraldic achievement, see image</ref> He lies recumbent, in full armour, propped up on his right elbow, with his two widows kneeling at prayer at his head and feet.<ref name=A5 /> It was probably constructed by John Deymond, an Exeter mason.<ref name=Pev215 /> The Renaissance style<ref name=H352 /> comprises columns, [[strapwork]], cartouches, obelisks, fruit and [[Putto|putti]]<ref name=Pev215 /> It displays the following Latin inscriptions:<ref name=P5 /> ''Anno Domini 1613''; ''Mors janua vitae'' (Death is the gateway to life) and the well-known ''Mors mihi lucrum''<ref>St Paul's Epistle to the Philippians , 1:21</ref> (Death to me is reward); ''Post tenebras spero lucem'' (After darkness I hope for light); ''Caro mea requiescit in spe'' (May my flesh rest in hope); ''A Deo omnis victoria'' (All victory comes from God). A rectangular space above his effigy which should have contained a marble tablet inscribed with his epitaph remains blank, as it was in 1697 when described by John Prince.<ref name=P5 />
===Armorials=== At the top of the monument is a heraldic [[Achievement (heraldry)|achievement]] of Sir John Acland (died 1620), showing an escutcheon [[Quartering (heraldry)|quarterly]] of 6: *1st:Acland, with a crescent or for [[Difference (heraldry)|difference]] of a 2nd son; *2nd: ''Argent, above a bend wavy sable a man's hand couped at the wrist in a glove lying fessways thereon a falcon perched, all or''; *3rd: *4th: ''Argent, two bendlets wavy sable'' (Stapledon of [[Annery, Monkleigh|Annery]]) *5th: ''Argent a bend engrailed sable'' (Radcliffe), as borne by [[Robert Radcliffe, 1st Earl of Sussex]] (died 1542); *6th: ''Or, on a fesse dancetté between three billets azure each charged with a [[Lions in heraldry|lion rampant]] of the first three [[bezant]]s'' (Rolle).
Crest above: ''a man's hand couped at the wrist in a glove lying fessways thereon a falcon perched, all proper'' (Acland)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

London and Chichester: Phillimore, 1981 *Dictionary of National Biography, London: Smith, Elder & Co. 1885–1900, "Acland, John (died 1613)" *[http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1558-1603/member/acland-john-1552-1620 Hasler, P.W. (ed.), The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1558–1603, 1981, biography of Sir John Acland] *[[John Prince (biographer)|Prince, John]], (1643–1723) The Worthies of Devon, 1810 edition, pp. 1–6 biography of Sir John Acland *[http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1604-1629/member/acland-sir-john-1553-1620 Venning, Tim & Hunneyball, Paul, biography of Sir John Acland, published in: The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1604–1629, ed. Andrew Thrush and John P. Ferris, 2010] *Vivian, Lt.Col. J.L., (Ed.) The Visitations of the County of Devon: Comprising the Heralds' Visitations of 1531, 1564 & 1620, Exeter, 1895, pp. 3–8, pedigree of Acland.

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = John Cranko | birth_name = | image = John Cranko.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1927|8|15|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Rustenburg]], [[South Africa]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1973|6|26|1927|8|15|df=yes}} | death_place = On board transatlantic flight | occupation = Ballet dancer and choreographer | spouse = | parents = Herbert and Grace Cranko | children = }}
'''John Cyril Cranko''' (15 August 1927 – 26 June 1973) was a South African born ballet dancer and [[choreographer]] with the [[Royal Ballet]] and the [[Stuttgart Ballet]].
==Life and career==
===Early life=== Cranko was born in [[Rustenburg]] in the former province of [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]], [[South Africa]]. As a child, he would put on puppet shows as a creative outlet. Cranko received his early ballet training in Cape Town under the leading South African ballet teacher and director, [[Dulcie Howes]], of the [[University of Cape Town]] Ballet School. In 1945 he choreographed his first work (using Stravinsky's Suite from ''The Soldier's Tale'') for the Cape Town Ballet Club.<ref>[http://www.stuttgart-ballet.de/company/john-cranko/ "John Cranko"], Stuttgart Ballet, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref> He then moved to London, studying with the Sadler's Wells Ballet School in 1946 <ref name=dnb>Dromgoole, Nicholas. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/30978 "John Cranko"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', retrieved 19 March 2015, {{ODNBsub}}</ref> and dancing his first role with the Sadler's Wells Ballet in November 1947.<ref>[http://rohcollections.org.uk/SearchResults.aspx?searchtype=performance&page=0&person=Cranko "John Cranko"], Royal Opera House Performance Database, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref>
===London=== Cranko collaborated with the designer [[John Piper (artist)|John Piper]] on ''Sea Change'', performed at the [[Gaiety Theatre, Dublin]] in July 1949. They collaborated again for Sadler's Wells Ballet on ''The Shadow'', which opened on 3 March 1953.<ref name=RCM2008_94>Reed, Cooke & Mitchell, p. 94</ref> This period marked a transition in Cranko's career from dancer to full-time choreographer, with his last performance for the Sadler's Wells Ballet taking place in April 1950.<ref>[http://rohcollections.org.uk/SearchResults.aspx?searchtype=performance&page=2&person=Cranko "John Cranko"], Royal Opera House Performance Database, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref> At 23 years old, he was appointed as resident choreographer for Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet's 1950–51 season.<ref>"John Cranko", Programme booklet for ''[[Onegin (Cranko)|Onegin]]'', Royal Opera House, Covent Garden 2014–2015 season, p. 31</ref>
For the company's [[Festival of Britain]] season in 1951 Cranko choreographed the comic [[ballet]] ''[[Pineapple Poll]]'',<ref>{{Cite web| title = John Cranko - Pineapple Poll - YouTube| accessdate = 2018-08-31| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SJG89TSSw8}}</ref> to the music of [[Arthur Sullivan]] (newly out of copyright) arranged by the conductor [[Charles Mackerras]].<ref name=dnb/> Another collaboration with Mackerras followed in 1954 with ''[[The Lady and the Fool]]'', to music by [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]].<ref name=dnb/> In January 1954 Sadler's Wells Ballet announced that Cranko was collaborating with [[Benjamin Britten]] to create a ballet. Cranko devised a draft scenario for a work he originally called ''The Green Serpent'', fusing elements drawn from ''[[King Lear]]'', ''Beauty and the Beast'' (a story he had choreographed for Sadler's Wells in 1948) and the oriental tale published by [[Madame d'Aulnoy]] as ''Serpentin Vert''. Creating a list of dances, simply describing the action and giving a total timing for each, he passed this to Britten and left him to compose what eventually became ''[[The Prince of the Pagodas]]''.<ref>Reed, Cooke & Mitchell, pp. 258–260</ref>
Cranko wrote and developed a musical revue ''Cranks'', which opened in London in December 1955, moved to a West End theatre the following March, and ran for 223 performances. With music by [[John Addison]], its cast of four featured the singers [[Anthony Newley]], [[Annie Ross]], Hugh Bryant and the dancer Gilbert Vernon; it transferred to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Bijou Theatre (Manhattan)|Bijou Theatre]]. An original cast CD has been released.<ref>{{cite web| title =Cranks | publisher =The Guide to Musical Theatre | date =2014 | url =http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_c/cranks.htm | accessdate = 26 June 2014 }}</ref> Cranko followed the format of ''Cranks'' with a new revue ''New Cranks'' opening at the Lyric Theatre Hammersmith on 26 April 1960 with music by David Lee and a cast including [[Gillian Lynne]], [[Carole Shelley]] and [[Bernard Cribbins]], but it failed to have the same impact.<ref name=dnb/>
In 1960, Cranko directed the first production of Benjamin Britten's opera ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream (opera)|A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', at the [[Aldeburgh Festival]].<ref>"A New Midsummer Night's Dream", ''The Times'', 11 June 1960, p. 11.</ref> When the work had its London premiere the following year at Covent Garden, Cranko was not invited to direct, and [[John Gielgud|Sir John Gielgud]] was brought in.<ref>"London Triumph for Britten's Dream", ''The Times'', 3 February 1961, p. 13</ref>
===Stuttgart=== Prosecuted for homosexual activity, Cranko left the UK for Stuttgart, and in 1961 was appointed director of the Stuttgart Ballet,<ref name=RCM2008_94/> where he assembled a group of talented performers such as [[Marcia Haydée]], [[Egon Madsen]], [[Richard Cragun]], [[Birgit Keil]] and [[Suzanne Hanke]]. Among his following choreographies were ''[[Romeo and Juliet (Cranko)|Romeo and Juliet]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]] in 1962, set to music by [[Sergei Prokofiev|Prokofiev]], ''[[Onegin (Cranko)|Onegin]]'' in 1965, an adaptation of the verse novel ''[[Eugene Onegin]]'' by [[Alexander Pushkin]], set to music by [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]] (mainly ''[[The Seasons (Tchaikovsky)|The Seasons]]''), orchestrated by [[Kurt-Heinz Stolze]], ''[[The Taming of the Shrew (ballet)|The Taming of the Shrew]]'' by Shakespeare in 1969, ''Brouillards'' in 1970, ''Carmen'' in 1971 (music by [[Wolfgang Fortner]] and [[Wilfried Steinbrenner]]) and ''Spuren (Traces)'' in 1973.
Cranko's work was a major contribution to the international success of German ballet beginning with a guest performance at the New York [[Metropolitan Opera]] in 1969. At Stuttgart, Cranko invited [[Kenneth MacMillan]] to work with the company, for whom MacMillan created four ballets in Cranko's lifetime and a fifth, ''[[Requiem (MacMillan)|Requiem]]'', as a tribute after Cranko's death.<ref>Parry, pp. 711–716</ref> At Cranko's instigation the company established its own ballet school in 1971; it was renamed the John Cranko Schule in his honour in 1974.<ref>[http://en.john-cranko-schule.de/history/ "History"] John Cranko Schule, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref> His assistant and choreologist [[Georgette Tsinguirides]] preserved his works in [[Benesh Movement Notation]].
Cranko choked to death after suffering an allergic reaction to a sleeping pill he took during a transatlantic charter flight from Philadelphia to Stuttgart two days after the company completed a successful tour of the United States at the [[Academy of Music (Philadelphia)|Academy of Music]] in Philadelphia. The flight made an emergency landing in Dublin where Cranko was pronounced dead upon arrival at a hospital.<ref>{{cite news|title="John Cranko Dies at 45; Stuttgart Ballet Director"|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/06/27/archives/john-cranko-dies-at-45-stuttgart-ballet-director-hurok-pays-tribute.html?_r=0|newspaper=The New York ''Times''|date=June 27, 1973}}</ref> His mother, Grace, who was divorced from Herbert and lived in what was then [[Rhodesia]], heard about his death from a radio broadcast. Cranko was buried at a small cemetery near [[Castle Solitude]] in Stuttgart.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}}
===Legacy=== In 2007, the Stuttgart Ballet celebrated what would have been Cranko's 80th birthday with the Cranko Festival.<ref>[http://www.arte.tv/de/das-stuttgarter-ballettwunder/1634898,CmC=1634922.html "Das Stuttgarter Ballettwunder"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112217/http://www.arte.tv/de/das-stuttgarter-ballettwunder/1634898%2CCmC%3D1634922.html |date= 2 April 2015 }}, Arte, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref> The ballet ''Voluntaries'' by [[Glen Tetley]] was created in his memory. The John Cranko Society in Stuttgart, founded in 1975, promotes knowledge of ballet and Cranko's work, supports performances and talented dancers, and every year presents the John Cranko Award.<ref>[http://www.john-cranko-gesellschaft.de/web/aktuelles.html "Aktuelles"], John-Cranko-Gesellschaft, retrieved 19 March 2015</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = John Gordon | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Ireland]] | death_date = {{Death date|1845|02|14}} | death_place = [[Providence, Rhode Island]] | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''John Gordon''' (died February 14, 1845) was the last person [[Capital punishment in Rhode Island|executed]] by [[Rhode Island]]. His conviction and execution have been ascribed by researchers to anti-[[Roman Catholic]] and anti-[[Ireland|Irish]] [[immigrant]] bias.<ref name="mckay">McKay, Scott. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080501000000*/http://www.projo.com/news/content/death_penalty_case_05-25-08_TCA892N_v56.2f760d1.html "Judge's old notes shed light on last execution in R.I."] ''[[Providence Journal]]''. May 25, 2008.</ref> As a result, he was posthumously pardoned in 2011.<ref name = pardon/>
In 1844, Gordon was tried and convicted for the December 31, 1843, beating [[murder]] of Amasa Sprague, a [[Cranston, Rhode Island|Cranston]] [[textile]] factory owner. Sprague was a member of a prominent Rhode Island family. His brother [[William Sprague III|William]] was a [[United States Senate|United States senator]]. Six months before his murder, Amasa Sprague had used his family's political influence to have Cranston resident Nicholas Gordon's [[liquor license]] removed by the city council.<ref name="mckay"/> (Sprague's employees were habitually getting drunk at Gordon's premises.) Nicholas Gordon and his brother John were [[Roman Catholic]] immigrants from [[Ireland]]. Nicholas, John and William Gordon (another brother) were all tried for murder, but only John was convicted, a conviction based on contradictory circumstantial evidence.<ref name="mckay"/> William was found not guilty and in Nicholas's case, held after John's execution, the [[jury]] was [[Hung jury|hung]]. John Gordon was executed by [[hanging]] in the state jail in [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]]. The court justices, which included Justice [[Job Durfee]], that were involved in all three trials acted as both trial judges and the court of final appeal.<ref name="hoffman">Hoffman, Charles G. and Tess Hoffmann (1998). ''Brotherly Love: Murder and the Politics of Prejudice in Nineteenth-Century Rhode Island''. Boston: [[University of Massachusetts Press]]. {{ISBN|1-55849-163-5}}.</ref> Included in jury instructions, Durfee "told the jurors to give greater weight to Yankee witnesses than Irish witnesses."<ref name="mckay"/>
Seven years after Gordon's execution, Rhode Island abolished the death penalty.<ref name="mckay"/> Although it was reintroduced in 1872, no executions took place before capital punishment was abolished again by the state in 1984. In the 1990s, when the [[Rhode Island General Assembly]] considered reinstating the death penalty, Gordon's case has been used by those against reinstatement to demonstrate the dangers of capital punishment.<ref name="mckay"/>
Rhode Island Governor [[Lincoln Chafee]] pardoned Gordon on June 29, 2011, following passage of legislation by the state's General Assembly urging such action.<ref name=pardon>Erika Niedowski, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110702114523/http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode_island/articles/2011/06/29/ri_governor_pardons_irish_man_hanged_in_1845/ "RI governor pardons Irish man hanged in 1845"], [[Associated Press]], 2011-06-29.</ref> The legislation was sponsored in the [[Rhode Island House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] by [[Peter F. Martin]] and in the [[Senate of Rhode Island|Senate]] by [[Michael McCaffrey]].<ref name = pardon/> Chafee signed the proclamation of pardon at the Old State House, where Gordon's trial had taken place more than 150 years before.<ref name = pardon/>
In September 2014, [[Enda Kenny]], the [[Taoiseach]] of Ireland, visited the Rhode Island Irish Famine Memorial and in a speech praised Chafee for pardoning Gordon.<ref>Simon Carswell, [http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/us/government-in-talks-to-set-up-direct-flight-between-shannon-and-rhode-island-1.1940633 "Government in talks to set up direct flight between Shannon and Rhode Island"], ''[[Irish Times]]'', 24 September 2014.</ref>
==See also== *[[List of wrongful convictions in the United States]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Paul Caranci, ''The Hanging and Redemption of John Gordon'' (History Press, 2013) *Patrick T. Conley, "The Origins of the Governor's Pardoning Power" in ''People, Places, Laws and Lore of the Ocean State'' (Rhode Island Publications Society, 2012).
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gordon, John}} [[Category:1845 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century executions by the United States]] [[Category:19th-century executions of American people]] [[Category:Irish people executed abroad]] [[Category:Executed Irish people]] [[Category:People executed by Rhode Island by hanging]] [[Category:People executed for murder]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:19th-century Irish people]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Rhode Island]] [[Category:Irish emigrants to the United States (before 1923)]] [[Category:People from Cranston, Rhode Island]] [[Category:Recipients of American gubernatorial pardons]] [[Category:People who have received posthumous pardons]] [[Category:People wrongfully convicted of murder]] [[Category:Wrongful executions]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Life Goes On | image = Life Goes On 2009 film poster.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = Sangeeta Dutta | producer = | writer = | starring = Girish Karnad
Sharmila Tagore
Om Puri
Soha Ali Khan | cinematography = | editing = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2009|10|30|Mumbai Film Festival}} | runtime = 120 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = }} '''''Life Goes On''''' is a 2009 film by Sangeeta Datta. It shows how a Hindu family in Britain copes with the death of the wife and mother. The story recalls Shakespeare’s ''[[King Lear]]''.{{cite news|title=Life Goes On – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/mar/13/life-goes-on-review|accessdate=3 October 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 March 2011|author=[[Philip French]]}} ==Plot== The film is set in modern London. The central character is Sanjay, a Hindu doctor, respected in his community. After the sudden death of his wife Manju, he struggles to relate to his three daughters. The drama follows the week from Manju's death to her funeral. As well as dealing with grief and family ties, the film addresses inter-faith issues as Sanjay discovers that the youngest daughter Dia has a Muslim boyfriend, Imtiaz. Wandering the streets of London the night before the funeral, Sanjay recalls his own childhood, when he left home with his parents during the [[partition of India]]. ==Cast== * [[Girish Karnad]] as Sanjay * [[Sharmila Tagore]] as Manju * [[Om Puri]] as Alok * [[Soha Ali Khan]] as Dia * [[Rez Kempton]] as Imtiaz * Neerja Naik as Tuli * Christopher Hatherall as John * Mukulika Banerjee as Lolita * [[Misha Crosby]] as Abbas * Tom Reed as Tom * Sue Parker-Nutley as Mrs Goldsmith ==Reception== The film won the Best Feature Film Award at the [[Pravasi International Film Festival]] in Delhi, and the Best Feature Film Audience Appreciation Award at the [[London Asian Film Festival]].{{cite news|title=We Shall Overcome|url=http://www.newslinemagazine.com/2011/02/movie-review-life-goes-on/|accessdate=3 October 2012|newspaper=[[Newsline (magazine)|Newsline]]|date=15 February 2011|author=Farieha Aziz|location=Pakistan}} Xan Brooks in the ''Guardian'' considered the acting "stiff and self-conscious".{{cite news|title=Life Goes On – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/mar/10/life-goes-on-review|accessdate=3 October 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=10 March 2011|author=Xan Brooks}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Life Goes On}} * {{official website|http://stormglassproductions.com/Stormglass/Life_Goes_On.html}} * {{IMDb title|id=1464549|title=Life Goes On}} {{King Lear}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Life Goes On}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British drama films]] [[Category:British Indian films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about drugs]] [[Category:Films set in London]]

{{for|a list of Egyptian mummies that are not royalty|List of Egyptian mummies (officials, nobles, and commoners)}} The following is a list of mummies that include Egyptian [[Pharaoh]]s and their named [[Ancient Egyptian funerary practices|mummified]] family members.{{efn|Mummies have been found by archaeologists whom have determined their royal status, but have not been able to provide any conclusive name. These mummies are not listed here as not enough information is available on the subject.}} Some of these mummies have been found to be remarkably intact, while others have been damaged from [[Grave robbery#Effects on archaeology around the world|tomb robbers]] and environmental conditions. Given the technology/wealth at the time, all known predynastic rulers were buried in open tombs. It was not until Pharaoh [[Den (pharaoh)|Den]] of the first dynasty that things such as a staircase and architectural elements were [[Den (pharaoh)#Tomb|added]] which provided better protection from the [[Weather|elements]].Shaw, Ian and Nicholson, Paul. The Dictionary of Ancient Egypt. p. 84. Harry N. His mummy is still there, and it indicates that he died around the age of ten.Dodson & Hilton, pp.135,141Betsy Bryan: ''The 18th Dynasty before the Amarna Period'', in Ian Shaw (editor): ''The Oxford History of Ancient Egypt'', Oxford, New York 2000, {{ISBN|978-0192804587}}, p. 248 |} ==Disputed== The following entries are previously identified mummies that are now in dispute. Over time through the advance in technology, new information comes to light that discredits old findings and beliefs. The mummies that have been lost or destroyed since initial discovery may never be properly identified. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 80%; |- ! scope="col" | Assumed name(s) ! scope="col" | Dynasty ! scope="col" | Sex ! scope="col" | Year discovered ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Image ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- | [[Ahmose-Nefertari]] | style="text-align: center;"| [[Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt|18th]] | Female | style="text-align: center;"| 1881 1881 | [[File:Mummy Ahmose-Nefertari Smith.JPG|90px]] | Ahmose-Nefertari is assumed to have been retrieved from her tomb at the end of the New Kingdom and moved to the royal cache in [[DB320]]. Her presumed body, with no identification marks, was discovered in the 19th century and unwrapped in 1885 by Emile Brugsch but this identification has been challenged.{{cite web|url=http://www.dylanb.me.uk/wp/?page_id=977|title=The so-called Royal Cachette TT 320 was not the grave of Ahmose Nefertari!|work=www.dylanb.me.uk|author=Dylan|date=July 22, 2014|accessdate=December 15, 2017}} When the mummy was found it emitted such a bad odor that it was reburied on museum grounds in Cairo until the offensive smell abated. If this is Ahmose-Nefertari, then she was determined to have died in her 70s. The mummy's hair had been thinning and plaits of false hair had been woven in with its own to cover this up. The body also had been damaged in antiquity and was missing its right hand.Tyldesley, Joyce. Chronicle of the Queens of Egypt. Thames & Hudson. 2006. {{ISBN|0-500-05145-3}} |- | [[Ahmose Sapair]] | style="text-align: center;"| 18th | Male | style="text-align: center;"| 1881 1881 | [[File:Sapair-cercueil-momie.jpg|90px]] | In 1881, a mummy of a 5- to 6-year-old boy was found in cache ([[DB320]]) and identified as Ahmose-Sipair. This was disputed as Prince Ahmose-Sipair is always portrayed as an adult on the coffin of the scribe and other antiquities, thus the child-mummy cannot be his.{{cite web|url=http://members.tripod.com/anubis4_2000/mummypages1/Early18.htm#Sipair|title=XVIII'th Dynasty Gallery I|work=The Theban Royal Mummy Project|accessdate=December 15, 2017}} |- | [[Akhenaten]] | style="text-align: center;"| 18th | Male | style="text-align: center;"| 1907 1907 | [[File:Akhenaten skull profile.png|90px]] | Uncertainty remains over the identity of this mummy as the young age at death is inconsistent with Akhenaten's reign. CT scans done in 2010 strongly suggest that the mummy may be Pharaoh [[Smenkhkare#Death and burial|Smenkhkare]]. |- | [[Ankhesenamun]] | style="text-align: center;"| 18th | Female | style="text-align: center;"| 1817 1817 | {{n/a}} | Believed to be [[Ankhesenamun]], as she is the mother of the two fetuses found in [[Tutankhamun]]'s grave. Uncertainty remains if the mummy found in [[KV55]] is accepted to be [[Akhenaten]]. She is also known as mummy [[Ankhesenamun#Mummy KV21A|KV21A]] from the tomb that she was discovered in. |- | [[Mayet (ancient Egypt)|Mayet]] | style="text-align: center;"| [[Eleventh Dynasty of Egypt|11th]] | Female | style="text-align: center;"| 1921 1921 | {{n/a}} | Mayet's position within the royal family of Mentuhotep II is disputed.Michael Rice: ''Who is who in Ancient Egypt''. Routledge, London/New York 1999. {{ISBN|978-0-203-44328-6}}, p. 117. It is generally assumed that she was a daughter of the king as she was about five years old when she died. |- | {{*}}[[Nefertiti]],
{{*}}[[Nebetah]], or
{{*}}[[Beketaten]] | style="text-align: center;"| 18th | Female | style="text-align: center;"| 1898 1898 | [[File:TheYoungerLady-61072-FrontView-PlateXCIX-TheRoyalMummies-1912.gif|90px]] | {{*}}'''Main article:''' [[The Younger Lady]]
Two main DNA tests have been done on this mummy which have resulted in three different possible identities. Early speculation was that the mummy belonged to [[Queen Nefertiti]], and while DNA testing was done it neither confirmed nor denied this as being factual. Another later DNA testing revealed her to be a daughter of Pharaoh [[Amunhotep III]], and the mother of [[Tutankhamun]]. This DNA report concluded that the mummy is likely [[Beketaten]], or [[Nebetah]], but again no conclusive answer was found. In any case the mummy was found to be extensively damaged by past tomb robbers which caused numerous holes. |- | [[Setnakhte]] | style="text-align: center;"| [[Twentieth Dynasty of Egypt|20th]] | Male | style="text-align: center;"| 1898 1898 | [[File:Setnacht Mummy.jpg|90px]] | The alleged mummy of Setnakhte has never been identified with certainty, although the so–called "mummy in the boat" found in [[KV35]] was sometimes identified with him, an attribution rejected by Aidan Dodson who rather believes the body belonged to a royal family member of [[Amenhotep II]] of the [[18th Dynasty]]. In any case the mummy was destroyed by looters in 1901, thus preventing any analysis on it.{{cite journal|first=Thomas|last=Schneider|year=2010|title=Contributions to the Chronology of the New Kingdom and the Third Intermediate Period|journal=Ägypten & Levante|pp=|url=|volume=20}}, pp. 386–387 |- | [[Tetisheri]] | style="text-align: center;"| [[Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt|17th]]/18th | Female | style="text-align: center;"| 1881 1881 | [[File:Tetisheri mummy.jpg|90px]] | No tomb has yet been conclusively identified with Queen Tetisheri, though a mummy that may be hers was included among other members of the royal family that were reburied in the Royal Cache. |- | [[Thutmose I]] | style="text-align: center;"| 18th | Male | style="text-align: center;"| 1881 1881 | [[File:Thutmose I mummy head.png|90px]] | Egyptologist [[Gaston Maspero]] thought this was the mummy of Thutmose I largely on the strength of familial resemblance to the mummies of Thutmose II and Thutmose III. In 2007 though, [[Zahi Hawass|Dr. Zahi Hawass]] announced that the mummy is a thirty-year-old man who had died as a result of an arrow wound to the chest. Due to the young age of the mummy and the cause of death, it was determined that the mummy was probably not of Thutmose I.{{Cite news | last = Anderson | first = Lisa | title = Mummy awakens new era in Egypt | newspaper = Chicago Tribune | pages = | date = 14 July 2007 | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-07-14/news/0707130698_1_mummy-18th-dynasty-ct-scan | postscript = }} |} ==See also== *[[List of bog bodies]] *[[List of pharaohs]] *[[Animal mummy]] *[[Valley of the Kings]] *[[Valley of the Queens]] *[[List of Theban tombs]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|20em}} {{Mummies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List of Egyptian mummies}} [[Category:Lists of people by aspect of death|Mummies]] [[Category:Mummies| ]] [[Category:Death-related lists|Mummies]] [[Category:Ancient Egypt-related lists|mummies royalty]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian mummies]]

{{technical|date=April 2017}}
'''Murray's law''' predicts the thickness of branches in transport networks, such that the cost for transport and maintenance of the transport medium is minimized. This law is observed in the [[vascular]] and [[respiratory systems]] of animals, [[xylem]] in plants, and the respiratory system of insects.<ref name="Zheng2017"/><ref name="sherman">{{cite journal|last=Sherman|first=Thomas F.|year=1981|title=On connecting large vessels to small. The meaning of Murray's law|url=http://jgp.rupress.org/cgi/reprint/78/4/431.pdf|format=pdf|journal=The Journal of General Physiology|volume=78|issue=4|page=a 431–453|doi=10.1085/jgp.78.4.431|pmc=2228620|pmid=7288393}}</ref><ref name="williams" /><ref name="mcculloh">{{cite journal|last=McCulloh|first=Katherine A.|author2=John S. Sperry|author3=Frederick R. Adler|year=2003|title=Water transport in plants obeys Murray's law|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v421/n6926/full/nature01444.html|journal=Nature|volume=421|issue=6926|pages=939–942|doi=10.1038/nature01444|pmid=12607000}}</ref> Its simplest version states that if a branch of [[radius]] <math>r</math> splits into two branches of radii <math>r_1</math> and <math>r_2</math>, then <math>r^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3</math>. Like [[Hagen-Poiseuille Law]] and [[Fick's Law]], which were also formulated from a biological context, Murray’s law is a basic physical principle for transfer networks.<ref name="sherman" /><ref name="mcculloh" />
Murray's law is also a powerful [[biomimetics]] design tool in engineering. It has been applied in the design of [[self-healing material]]s, [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]], [[photocatalysts]], and [[gas sensors]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} However, since its discovery, little attention has been paid to exploit this law for designing advanced materials, reactors and industrial processes for maximizing mass or energy transfer to improve material performance and process efficiency.<ref name="williams" />
The original version of Murray's law is only applicable to [[Conservation of mass|mass-conservative]] transport in the network. There are generalizations for non-conservative networks, which describe effects such as chemical reactions and diffusion through the walls.<ref name="Zheng2017">{{Cite journal |last=Zheng|first=Xianfeng |last2=Shen|first2=Guofang |last3=Wang|first3=Chao |last4=Li|first4=Yu |last5=Dunphy|first5=Darren |last6=Hasan|first6=Tawfique |last7=Brinker|first7=C. Jeffrey |last8=Su|first8=Bao-Lian |date=2017-04-06 |title=Bio-inspired Murray materials for mass transfer and activity |url=http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14921 |journal=Nature Communications |language=en |volume=8 |doi=10.1038/ncomms14921 |issn=2041-1723}}</ref>
== Murray's law in mass-conservative networks ==
Murray's original analysis<ref name="murray1">{{cite journal|last=Murray|first=Cecil D.|year=1926|title=The Physiological Principle of Minimum Work: I. The Vascular System and the Cost of Blood Volume|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=12|issue=3|pages=207–214|doi=10.1073/pnas.12.3.207|pmc=1084489|pmid=16576980}}</ref><ref name="murray2">{{cite journal|last=Murray|first=Cecil D.|year=1926|title=The Physiological Principle of Minimum Work: II. Oxygen Exchange in Capillaries|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=12|issue=5|pages=299–304|doi=10.1073/pnas.12.5.299|pmc=1084544|pmid=16587082}}</ref> is based on the assumption that the radii inside a [[Lumen (anatomy)|lumen]]-based system are such that '''the [[Work (physics)|work]] for transport and upkeep is minimized'''. Larger vessels lower the expended energy for transport, but increase the overall volume of blood in the system; blood being a living fluid and hence requiring metabolic support. Murray's law is therefore an optimisation exercise to balance these factors.
For <math>n</math> child branches splitting from a common parent branch, the law states that:
<math>r^3 = r_1^3 + r_2^3 + r_3^3 +...+ r_n^3</math>
where <math>r</math> is the radius of the parent branch, and <math>r_1, \ldots, r_n</math> are the radii of the child branches. This law is only valid for [[laminar flow]], since its derivation uses the [[Hagen-Poiseuille equation]] as a measure for the transport work (see below). Williams et al. deduced the formula for [[turbulent flow]]:<ref name="williams">{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=Hugo R.|year=2008|title=Minimum mass vascular networks in multifunctional materials|url=http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/5/18/55.full|journal=Journal of the Royal Society Interface|volume=5|issue=18|pages=55–65|doi=10.1098/rsif.2007.1022|pmc=2605499|pmid=17426011|author2=Trask, Richard S.|author3=Weaver, Paul M.|author4=Bond, Ian P.}}</ref>
<math>r^{(7/3)} = r_1^{(7/3)} + r_2^{(7/3)} + r_3^{(7/3)} + ... + r_n^{(7/3)} </math>
=== Derivation ===
As stated above, the underlying assumption of the Murray's law is that the [[Power (physics)|power]] ([[energy (physics)|energy]] per [[time]]) for transport and upkeep is minimal in a natural transport system. Hence we seek to minimize <math>P = P_t + P_m</math>, where <math>P_t</math> is the power required for transport and <math>P_m</math> the power required to maintain the transport medium (e.g. blood).
==== Laminar Flow ====
We first minimize the power of transport and upkeep in a single channel of the system, i.e. ignore bifurcations. Together with the assumption of mass-conservation this will yield the law. Let <math>Q</math> be the [[laminar flow|laminar]] [[volumetric flow rate|flow rate]] in this channel, which is assumed to be fixed. The power for transport in a laminar flow is <math>P_t = Q \Delta p</math>, where <math>\Delta p</math> is the pressure difference between the entry and exit of a tube of radius <math>r</math> and length <math>l</math>. The [[Hagen-Poiseuille Law]] for laminar flow states that <math display="inline">Q = \frac{\pi\,r^4}{8\,\mu\,l}\Delta p</math> and hence <math display="inline">\Delta p = \frac{8\,\mu\,l}{\pi\,r^4} Q</math> , where <math>\mu</math> is the [[dynamic viscosity]] of the fluid. Substituting this into the equation for <math>P_t</math>, we get<math display="block">P_t = \frac{8\,\mu\,l}{\pi\,r^4} Q^2.</math>We furthermore make the assumption that the power necessary for maintenance is proportional to the [[Volume#Volume formulas|volume of the cylinder]] <math>V = \pi\,l\,r^2</math> :<math display="block">P_m = \lambda\,V = \lambda\,\pi\,l\,r^2</math>where <math>\lambda > 0</math> is a constant number (metabolic factor). This yields<math display="block">P = P_t + P_m = \frac{8\,\mu\,l}{\pi\,r^4} Q^2 + \lambda\,\pi\,l\,r^2. </math>Since we seek the radius with minimal power, we calculate the [[stationary point]] with respect to r <math display="block">{\operatorname{d}\over\operatorname{d}\!r} P = 0 \;\Leftrightarrow\; - \frac{32\,\mu\,l}{\pi\,r^5} Q^2 + 2\,\lambda\,\pi\,l\,r = 0 \;\Leftrightarrow\; Q^2 = \frac{\pi^2}{16} \frac{\lambda}{\mu} r^6 \;\Leftarrow\; Q = \frac{\pi}{4} \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{\mu}} r^3. </math>With this relationship between the flow rate <math>Q</math> and radius <math>r</math> on an arbitrary channel, we return to the bifurcation: Since mass is conserved, the flow rate of the parent branch <math>Q</math> is the sum of the flow rates in the children branches <math>Q_1, \ldots, Q_n</math>. Since in each of these branches the power is minimized, the relationship above holds and hence, as claimed:<math display="block"> Q = \sum_{i=1}^N Q_i \;\Rightarrow\; \frac{\pi}{4} \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{\mu}} \, r^3 = \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{\pi}{4} \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{\mu}}\, r_i^3 \; \Rightarrow\; r^3 = \sum_{i=1}^N r_i^3.</math>
==== Diffusion ====
The power for transport spent by diffusion is given by
<math>P_t = Q\,\Delta C = \left( \pi\,D\,r^2 \frac{\Delta C}{l}\right) \Delta C</math>
where the flow rate is given by Fick's Law, whose <math>D</math> is the diffusivity constant and <math>\Delta C</math> is the difference of concentration between the ends of the cylinder. Similarly to the case of laminar flow, the minimisation of the objective function results in
<math> \frac{\Delta C}{l} = \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{D}} \Rightarrow Q = \pi\,D\,r^2 \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{D}} \Leftrightarrow Q = k\,r^2</math>
Hence,
<math> Q_p = \sum_{i=1}^N Q_i \Rightarrow k\, r_p^2 = \sum_{i=1}^N k\, r_i^2 \Leftrightarrow r_p^2 = \sum_{i=1}^N r_i^2</math>
== The generalized Murray’s law ==
However, the special Murray’s law is only applicable to flow processes involving no mass variations. Significant theoretical advances need to be made for more broadly applicable in the fields of chemistry, applied materials, and industrial reactions. [[File:Murray_networks.jpg|left|thumb|143x143px|Murray networks. ([[c:File:Murray_networks.jpg|Zheng, CC-BY-SA]]) ]]'''[https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14921 The generalized Murray's law]''' deduced by Zheng et al. can be applicable for optimizing mass transfer involving mass variations and chemical reactions involving flow processes, molecule or ion diffusion, etc.<ref name="Zheng2017"/> For connecting a parent pipe with radius of '''''r<sub>0</sub>''''' to many children pipes with radius of '''''r<sub>i</sub>''''' , the formula of generalized Murray's law is: <math>r_o^a={1 \over 1-X}\sum_{i=1}^Nr_i^a</math>, where the '''''X''''' is the ratio of mass variation during mass transfer in the parent pore, the exponent '''''α''''' is dependent on the type of the transfer. For laminar flow ''α'' =3; for turbulent flow ''α'' =7/3; for molecule or ionic diffusion ''α'' =2; etc.
[https://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/leaf-vein-structure-could-hold-key-to-extending-battery-life I t is applicable to an enormous range of porous materials and has a broad scope in functional ceramics and nano-metals for energy and environmental applications].
== Murray materials ==
The generalized Murray’s law defines the basic geometric features for porous materials with optimum transfer properties. The generalized Murray’s law can be used to design and optimize the structures of an enormous range of porous materials. This concept has led to materials, termed as the [https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14921 '''Murray materials'''], whose pore-sizes are multiscale and are designed with diameter-ratios obeying the generalized Murray’s law.<ref name="Zheng2017" /> [[File:Murray materials.jpg|thumb|A diagram of Murray materials with macro-meso-micropores built by nanopaticles as building blocks. ([[c:File:Murray_materials.jpg|Zheng, CC-BY-SA]]) |left|215x215px]][http://www.greencarcongress.com/2017/04/20170407-murray.html As lithium battery electrodes, the Murray materials can reduce the stresses in these electrodes during the charge/discharge processes, improving their structural stability and resulting in a longer life time for energy storage devices.] [http://www.msn.com/en-za/news/techandscience/leaf-veins-may-lead-to-longer-battery-life/ar-BBzDHW9 This material could also be used for boosting the performance of a gas sensor and a photocatalysis process that broke down a dye using light.] [[File:Murray materials in leaf and insect with a parent pore (radius r0) connecting to many children pores (radius ri). .jpg|thumb|279x279px|Murray materials in leaf and insect. ([[c:File:Murray_materials_in_leaf_and_insect_with_a_parent_pore_(radius_r0)_connecting_to_many_children_pores_(radius_ri)._.jpg|Zheng, CC-BY-SA]]) ]] To achieve substances or energy transfer with extremely high efficiency, evolution by natural selection has endowed many classes of organisms with Murray materials, in which the pore-sizes regularly decrease across multiple scales and finally terminate in size-invariant units. For example, in [[plant stem]]s and [[Leaf|leaf veins]], the sum of the radii cubed remains constant across every branch point to maximize the flow conductance, which is proportional to the rate of photosynthesis. For [[insect]]s relying upon gas diffusion for breathing, the sum of radii squared of tracheal pores remains constant along the diffusion pathway, to maximize gases diffusion. From plants, animals and materials to industrial processes, [https://uk.news.yahoo.com/leaf-vein-structure-might-help-114254703.html the introduction of Murray material concept to industrial reactions can revolutionize the design of reactors with highly enhanced efficiency, minimum energy, time, and raw material consumption for a sustainable future.]

{{Expand Portuguese|Nicolau dos Reis Lobato|date=March 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{Infobox President | name=Nicolau Lobato | image = Rotunda do Aeroporto.jpg | caption = | nationality=[[East Timor]]ese | order= [[President of East Timor]]
{{small|Acting}} | term_start=7 December 1975 | term_end=31 December 1978 | predecessor=[[Francisco Xavier do Amaral]] | successor=[[Sérgio Vieira de Mello]] as UN Administrator 1999–2002
[[Xanana Gusmão]] as President 2002–2007 | order2= 1st [[Prime Minister of East Timor]] | term_start2=28 November 1975 | term_end2=7 December 1975 | predecessor2=''Position Established'' | successor2= [[Mari Alkatiri]] (as Prime Minister in 2002) | birth_date={{birth date|df=yes|1946|5|24}} | birth_place=[[Bazartete]], [[Portuguese Timor]] | death_date={{death date and age|df=yes|1978|12|31|1946|5|24}} | death_place= | spouse=Isabela Lobato | party=Fretilin | vicepresident= | religion=[[Roman Catholic]] }} '''Nicolau dos Reis Lobato''' (24 May 1946 – 31 December 1978) was an [[East Timor|East-Timorese]] politician and national hero. He was born in 1946 in [[Soibada]], [[Portuguese Timor]]. Lobato as 1st [[Prime Minister of East Timor]] from 28 November to 7 December 1975. Upon the arrival of the [[Indonesian military]] Lobato, along with other key [[Fretilin]] leaders, fled into the Timorese hinterland to fight against the occupying forces. On the final day of 1978 Lobato was ambushed by Indonesian special forces led by Lieutenant [[Prabowo|Prabowo Subianto]] (later son-in-law of President Suharto). He was killed after being shot in the stomach, and his body was brought to Dili to be inspected by Indonesian press. What then happened to his body is unknown, but the East-Timorese government continues to pursue the issue with the Indonesian government, so that his remains can be given a proper burial.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-21/new-push-to-find-ex-east-timor-pm-dos-reis-lobartos-body/9468250 East Timor's latest attempt to find the body of its first prime minister Nicolau dos Reis Lobato] ''ABC News'', 21 February 2018. Retrieved 24 February 2018. Nicolau Lobato was made an East Timorese national hero. The East Timor International Airport has been named in his honour ([[Presidente Nicolau Lobato International Airport]]). Dili International Airport.JPG|Nicolau Lobato International Airport F-FDTL-Centro de Instrução-Metinaro-2009.JPG| Military centre "Comandante Nicolau Lobato" Präsidentenpalast 17-05-2015.jpg|[[Nicolau Lobato Presidential Palace]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://mercosulcplp.blogspot.de/2009/12/timor-lestebiografia-do-presidente.html?spref=fb Biography of Nicolau Lobato in Portuguese], [http://timorleste.livejournal.com/204899.html English translation] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box| before=[[Mário Lemos Pires]] ''as Governor of [[Portuguese Timor]]'' (18 November 1974 – 27 November 1975)| years=28 November – 7 December 1975| title=[[Prime Ministers of East Timor]]
(UDI government)| after=[[Sérgio Vieira de Mello]] as UN Administrator (25 October 1999 – 19 May 2002) and [[Mari Alkatiri]] (from 2002)}} {{succession box| before=[[Francisco Xavier do Amaral]]| years=1975–1978| title=[[Presidents of East Timor]] – nominal| after= [[Sérgio Vieira de Mello]] as UN Administrator (25 October 1999 – 19 May 2002) and [[Xanana Gusmão]] (from 2002)}} {{s-end}} {{President of East Timor}} {{East Timor prime minister}} {{EastTimor-politician-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lobato, Nicolau dos Reis}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:People from Liquiçá District]] [[Category:Mambai people]] [[Category:Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor politicians]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of East Timor]] [[Category:Presidents of East Timor]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in East Timor]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]]
